Hi Mark;

Where in Canada are you.  There are some very good study groups in Canada 
and opportunity to learn and collect swords and fittings.

John
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Mark Jaillet" <mjaillet@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 12:22 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Hi Ron,
Anthony should try collecting up here in Canada! Now THAT
is a challenge. I for one would be more than interested to know what you
have to offer and suggestions would be more than appreciated. I'd be more
than happy to [ay in "lobster" or "hockey skates"! LOL!!!!

Kind regards, Mark



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 10:04 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Anthony -

Sorry to sound like such a "merchant" but if you're interested I can send
you some pictures of a very nice selection of good quality iron tsuba that
I'm selling. Most are $200 range, more or less. If you are new at this I
would be happy to recommend good ones that would help teach you about these
things. Some of these have been to a number of shows and are now kept home
so that I can keep my table at the shows, fresh. All are authentic, for
sure. The shows seem to have a wonderful selection of nice quality tsuba
these days and that is good for the buyer, bad for the seller since there is
such a "selection" to pick from. Anyway...just thought I'd toss this idea
out to you. I've been around for going on 40 years...gosh, that's a little
frightening to put in writing!

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: anwahi
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 4:23 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


Hello,

I'm new here and to collecting Tsuba. Where do you buy your Tsuba from?
I know there's several websites you can find with a Google search, an
occasional Token Kai show like the one in SF, or Ebay (most look like
junk). I'm looking for good sources of authentic Tsuba. Obviously the
only way to be really sure of authenticity is to purchase papered
Tsuba, but because I'm starting off I want some sources of authentic
Tsuba more reasonably priced. Any suggestions?

Thanks for your helpo in advance,
Anthony
